Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story: I stared at the email from my child’s school, my heart sinking as I read the words: “Your child was involved in a bullying incident today.” The principal wanted to meet as soon as possible. As a parent, I knew I needed to be there, to show my child that I take this seriously, to listen, to help them understand the gravity of their actions. But as I glanced at the clock, I remembered the stack of research data waiting on my desk. I was in the middle of a crucial experiment, and while the logs could technically be updated later, I prided myself on keeping meticulous, real-time records. My lab team expected nothing less. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my child needed me to be present and supportive, but my work demanded accuracy and consistency. I could feel the anxiety rising, torn between the urge to rush to the school and the responsibility to uphold my standards as a scientist. I sat frozen, caught between two roles that both mattered deeply, unsure which expectation I would have to let down.
